0.text: Sadness is a natural emotion that all people experience from time to time. It can be a reaction to specific events or situations. However, when sadness becomes persistent and affects daily life, it may be a sign of depression.
0.fact: According to the World Health Organization, about 5% of adults worldwide suffer from depression. Early detection and seeking help can significantly improve quality of life and contribute to faster recovery.

1.text: Fear is a natural reaction to threats. It helps us avoid danger and protect ourselves. However, when fear becomes persistent and does not correspond to the actual threat, it may be a sign of depression.
1.fact: Research shows that about 20% of people experience feelings of fear and anxiety related to the future, especially in times of uncertainty and instability. Understanding and managing these feelings can help improve mental health and quality of life.

2.text: Feelings of failure and negative self-esteem are common companions of depression. People tend to perceive their successes as less significant and their failures as more important than they really are.
2.fact: It is important to note that in most cases, people tend to exaggerate their failures. According to the American Psychological Association, only 25% of people who consider themselves failures have objective reasons for such thoughts.

3.text: The ability to take pleasure in everyday things, such as hobbies, food, or socializing with loved ones, is called anhedonia. This is one of the key symptoms of depression.
3.fact: It is important to understand that anhedonia can be caused by various factors, including biological (e.g., changes in neurotransmitter levels) and psychological (e.g., chronic stress or trauma).

4.text: Guilt is a natural emotion that helps us regulate behavior and maintain social connections. However, constant or excessive guilt can be a symptom of depression.
4.fact: Chronic guilt can lead to the development of other mental disorders, such as anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

5.text: Therapies, including cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT), have proven effective in reducing the fear of judgment. These methods help change negative thought patterns and improve self-acceptance.
5.fact: According to the National Institute of Mental Health in the USA, about 12% of people experience social anxiety during their lives.

6.text: Practices of self-compassion and acceptance of one's imperfections have proven effective in combating self-hatred. Studies show that people who practice meditation and mindfulness are less likely to experience strong self-critical attitudes.
6.fact: Self-hatred is a common symptom of depression and anxiety disorders. It can lead to the development of other mental disorders, such as personality disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

7.text: Self-criticism is an internal dialogue in which we judge and criticize ourselves for mistakes and failures. This pattern of thinking often accompanies depression and anxiety disorders.
7.fact: Oprah Winfrey, the well-known television host and entrepreneur, has repeatedly shared her stories of struggling with self-criticism. In her interviews and books, she talked about how hard it was for her to accept her mistakes and missteps on the way to success. Oprah actively promotes practices of self-compassion and self-acceptance, which have helped her overcome negative feelings and achieve inner peace.

8.text: Suicidal thoughts are a serious symptom of depression and other mental disorders. It is important to understand that the presence of such thoughts requires immediate attention and support from professionals.
8.fact: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), about 800,000 people die by suicide each year. It is one of the leading causes of death among young people aged 15 to 29.

9.text: Chronic worry can affect physical health, causing symptoms such as headaches, muscle tension, and digestive problems. Research shows that anxiety disorders are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
9.fact: Adele, the famous British singer, has openly spoken about her struggles with anxiety and panic attacks. Despite her enormous success, she often felt intense anxiety before performances and in daily life. Adele has used various methods, including therapy and meditation, to cope with her anxieties.

10.text: Lack of sleep and fatigue can significantly increase irritability levels. Studies show that chronic sleep deprivation leads to an increase in stress hormones such as cortisol, which intensifies irritability.
10.fact: According to the American Psychological Association, about 50% of people with depression report constant irritability as a major symptom.

11.text: Participating in support groups or therapeutic groups can help restore interest in socializing. These groups provide a safe space to express feelings and receive support from others facing similar issues.
11.fact: J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, shared in one of her interviews about her experience with depression when she felt a loss of interest in people and socializing. She emphasized the importance of social support and professional help in overcoming this condition.

12.text: Neuropsychological research shows that depression can alter activity in the prefrontal cortex of the brain, an area responsible for decision-making and planning.
12.fact: Psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), can help improve decision-making skills. CBT helps people develop more adaptive thinking strategies and reduce the impact of negative emotions on cognitive processes.

13.text: Changes in self-perception are often associated with psychological conditions such as depression and anxiety disorders. People with depression often have a negative perception of themselves and their appearance, even if their appearance has not objectively changed.
13.fact: Lady Gaga, the well-known singer and actress, has openly discussed her struggles with body dysmorphia and depression. She shared that she often felt unattractive and worried about her appearance despite recognition and success.

14.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide. It affects more than 264 million people and leads to significant economic losses due to reduced productivity.
14.fact: Psychotherapy, particularly cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and medication treatments can help restore motivation and improve the ability to perform work duties. CBT helps people develop more adaptive thinking strategies and cope with negative emotions.

15.text: Sleep quality is directly related to mental health. Lack of sleep can worsen mood, cognitive functions, and overall well-being, creating a vicious cycle where poor sleep worsens mental health, and poor mental health worsens sleep.
15.fact: Insomnia increases the risk of developing depression and anxiety disorders by 20-40%.

16.text: Constant fatigue is one of the most common symptoms of depression and chronic stress. Fatigue can manifest as both physical and mental, reducing the ability to perform daily tasks and participate in social interactions.
16.fact: Winston Churchill, the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, suffered from depression, which he referred to as his "black dog." Churchill often mentioned his constant fatigue and lack of energy despite his active and productive life.

17.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), depression is the leading cause of changes in eating habits and eating disorders in adults.
17.fact: Healthy eating and regular meals can help stabilize appetite and improve overall mental health. Research shows that diets rich in omega-3 fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals can help reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety.

18.text: Weight changes can be the result of changes in appetite and eating habits associated with depression and anxiety disorders. Unintentional significant weight changes often serve as an indicator of serious emotional problems.
18.fact: Carrie Fisher, the famous actress known for her role in "Star Wars," openly discussed her struggles with depression and bipolar disorder. She shared how these conditions affected her weight and appetite. Carrie actively advocated for mental health awareness and the importance of seeking help.

19.text: Somatization is the process by which psychological stress manifests through physical symptoms such as pain, digestive issues, or dental problems. This is often observed in people with depression and anxiety disorders.
19.fact: Psychological state can significantly affect pain perception. Research shows that depression and anxiety can lower the pain threshold and increase sensitivity to physical discomfort.

20.text: Changes in hormone levels, such as serotonin and dopamine, play a key role in regulating mood and sexual interest. Depression and anxiety disorders can disrupt the balance of these hormones, leading to decreased libido.
20.fact: Research shows that about 70% of people with depression experience decreased libido and sexual interest.

mild.text: Your condition is still within normal limits, but you may feel some instability. In such a case, improvement and a little mental 'tuning' wouldn't hurt. Cognitive therapy methods can be extremely helpful here. Everyone faces problems in everyday life, and a small change in perspective can often have a significant positive impact on how you feel.
mild.title: Mild Depression

moderate.text: You have moderate depression. You may experience quite strong negative feelings. If your score remains in this range for more than two weeks, professional help is necessary.
moderate.title: Moderate Depression

exacerbated.text: Your level of depressive disorder is extremely high. Likely, you are experiencing an exacerbation of usually moderate depression. Specialist help is required.
exacerbated.title: Exacerbated Depressive State

text: The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) is one of the most effective ways to detect the presence of depression and its stage. We recommend regularly taking this test and using its results as a guide in the treatment process.

Although simple to administer, the BDI test is reliable. A large number of studies over the past decades have shown that the BDI and similar tests are highly effective in identifying disorders. Despite this, we advise in any case to discuss the test results with a pscyhologist and not to make the diagnosis on your own.
